audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing "the legend himself, Paul Sawyer, from Warlord Games." He describes Sawyer's titles with an excited tone: "Head of Design, Chief Wizard, and Master of Recipes." The second male speaker responds humbly, acknowledging the introduction, saying "Well that's a, that's an intro" and expressing his desire to live up to it. The overall atmosphere suggests a lighthearted interview or conversation at a convention or event, due to the excited tone and the introduction of a figure of note in a field.

The audio clip starts with a conversation focusing on the launch of "Epic Package Shot," described as big news. The speaker mentions today being the launch day at a big show in the UK. A conversational tone is present between two speakers, one of whom makes a remark about the second day of a product launch. The tone shifts to playful jesting. In the background, ambient noise suggests a bustling environment.

The clip begins with a male speaker enthusiastically discussing a product, specifically mentioning the "big plastic Pike and Shot epic battles" game being on sale. He highlights that it works for the Thirty Years' War and English Civil War, noting that the product includes "two flag sheets." A female speaker interjects with excitement, praising the fact that customers "get both," referencing the flag sheets. The male speaker continues, explaining the game's flexibility for players to choose to play as either "Imperialists" or "Allies." He stumbles on the word "alliance" lightheartedly. He continues, explaining that the set has "epic pike and shot", before highlighting the cavalry as particularly interesting, noting the follow of the releases, from the gettysburg infantry. He mentions the landver as "all the other things we want to include" The speaker concludes by stating that the cavalry sprues are "a little bit of everything." He states that Thirty Years War "had a lot more cavalry".

The clip begins with a male speaker commenting on the nature of pikes and muskets. The speaker then mentions a "big block of pikemen" with musket sleeves and the need to cram in as much as possible. The speaker then refers to the cavalry who makes up the majority. Another male speaker describes what in essence covers light guns, medium guns, command shot, dragoons. The speaker concludes that it's a hefty sprue.

The clip begins with two male speakers in conversation, with one speaker stating that "...each of those elements are never going to merit their own screw in terms of their production cost" and the other countering, suggesting that when working with plastics, it's important to "get it right first time." The speaker emphasizes the planning that goes into their work, and then the conversation moves toward exploring different versions and feels, referencing fielding mass units. The clip ends with them discussing the possibility of bringing out a box set of, as the speaker says, "curassias." The sound of conversation takes place in what sounds like a busy public space, potentially an exhibition or conference, as there's steady background murmur of voices.

The clip features two male speakers discussing the next steps for plastic figures, specifically mentioning Scottish Covenanters, and referencing 3D prints. One speaker expresses surprise at the 3D printing capability and links the Covenant to a puritanical faction, implying a desire for their own way, paralleling modern times. The other speaker agrees and brings up a historical context of fighting for a king with their own prayer book and for Cromwell if needed. Background noise suggests a busy public area, possibly an event or fair, with audible chatter and general activity.

The clip begins with two male speakers discussing historical military uniforms, specifically the "Scott's Covenanters," "the Hodden Grey," and how those can be combined with existing plastics to create "Montrose's Scottish Royalists."  There is a discussion about the different flags and painting solutions and that it allows one to go beyond just Royalists and Parliamentarians. One of the speakers mentions working on a "Scott's hard plastic infantry sprue" currently in development. It's compared to the "common third player" unit and that it "looks different to all the other regiments," and it is compared, in a smaller scale, to the Prussians from Waterloo. A muskets sleeves and a frame gun are then mentioned.  The male speaker has a neutral to somewhat enthusiastic tone, and the other male speaker tends to agree.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing "Scott's Dragoons" to go on the frame and explains they are going to have the "famously smaller horses," emphasizing that they are a "little bit more weedy." He states, "Absolutely," when asked if that difference will be apparent. The speaker seems enthusiastic and mentions it's "big news" they'll get a still of. He then asks about Bolt Action, and the recording fades out.

The clip begins with two male speakers discussing a particular cabinet, one noting its connection to "Baking Shotton". One then points out another cabinet that contains a "pretty cabinet". They describe items within, including a "new plastic M4 A3 E8". One remarks that the commander figure resembles someone from a movie, though maybe "coincidentally". This transitions into mentioning a "matador", the second tank from the same film. They further mention the model's suitability for Korean War and World War Two scenarios. Finally, the clip mentions an "Italian Alpini" in plastic. Background speech provides context, while emphasizing the speaker's words.

The clip begins with sounds that suggest an indoor environment, potentially an event or fair, with background speech indicating multiple people talking. A male speaker emphasizes that the product in question is "third Italian plastic sprues." He continues to discuss the product's features and customizability, explaining it "gives you the options" with either the "helmet with the feather" or "the cap with the feather." A second male speaker reacts positively, followed by the first speaker explaining the design is "based very much on the existing plastic" with "similar bodies" but improved smartness. The second male speaker admits he anticipated a "ski guy," at which point the clip suddenly ends.

The clip features two male speakers engaged in an informal conversation. One speaker suggests that putting skis in a plastic sack "makes them pretty." The other speaker agrees, and they jokingly discuss the odds of carrying skis. They touch on the topic of ski troops and troops in winter gear, making references to adding layers in "Matlin Wolard Resin." In the background, indistinct speech and general ambient noise can be heard, contributing to a lively, possibly crowded, environment.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the painting of "the Alpini," referencing examples both painted and on the sprue, seemingly for an upcoming release scheduled this year, potentially in April and hopefully around August. The speaker sounds casual and somewhat hesitant to commit to a specific date, adding that his memory is a little shaky. A second male speaker responds and indicates it is good. The first male speaker then speaks of the companyâ€™s releases and excitement before transitioning to a discussion about "the bolt action stuff." A background of subtle mechanical sounds, possibly from equipment, permeates the audio.

The audio clip features a male speaker expressing surprise at the number of Italian sprues, stating that "doing one Italian sprue surprised me," and then adding that doing three different ones was "just astonishing." He ends his statement with "Italian out feeling." The man is speaking in an excited and somewhat surprised tone. There are no background sounds or other types of audio in this clip.

The audio clip begins with speech: A male speaker expresses his interest in "the Stalingrad campaign," stating he will be "looking forward to that." A subtle echo or reverberation can be heard. Following this, a distinct "boom" sound occurs.

The clip starts with a male speaker offering thanks for the other person's time, stating "thank you for your time, it's been a real pleasure." The speaker uses a polite and appreciative tone. In the background, speech is occurring, indicating other people are nearby.

The audio clip begins with the clinking of glasses, immediately followed by one speaker saying "Cheers." Someone responds with "Thank you, Baba." The clip features speech from two speakers; one male, and another speaker who identifies the other as "Baba," potentially suggesting familiarity or kinship.

The audio clip begins with someone saying "Hi" in a casual tone. Following this greeting, there is music playing. The music falls under the style of funk, evoking a groovy mood and featuring prominent keyboard melodies along with drums. There's some background hiss and crackle as the music continues.

The audio begins with an upbeat instrumental hip-hop piece featuring a drum machine, synth, and bassline, creating a groovy and energetic mood. The music stops, and a brief, possibly synthetic, "beep" sound is heard. Then, the hip-hop music fades back in.
